summary: This is an internal email chain from July 18, 2019, within the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, regarding a civilian caller who contacted a law enforcement intake line about the Epstein case. The email discusses routing the caller's voice message to the FBI for potential investigation and outlines a procedure for handling persistent or unsubstantiated civilian reports.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney
persons.context: The sender of the initial email forwarding a voice message from a civilian caller about the Epstein case to the appropriate tipline handler.

events.title: Civilian Call to Epstein Case Tipline
events.description: A civilian caller left a voice message on a law enforcement intake line regarding the Epstein case, which was misdirected as the line was intended for law enforcement only.

keyFacts: A civilian attempted to report information related to the Epstein case on July 18, 2019, but called a law enforcement-only intake line by mistake.
The U.S. Attorney's Office had a specific protocol to forward such calls to the FBI for assessment before potentially sending a standard form letter from the Civilian Crime Reports Unit.
The email indicates an effort to manage and filter public tips regarding the Epstein investigation, distinguishing between credible leads and unsubstantiated reports.
The correspondence reveals internal procedural steps for handling civilian tips within the Southern District of New York during the Epstein investigation.
